title: teamLab Borderless, a Digital Art Museum
address: 1-3-8 Aomi, Odaiba Palette Town 2F, Koto-ku, Tokyo, Japan,
description: Cool light museum with different light displays in each room. Great for taking cool pictures!

title: Tsukiji Fish Market
address: 4 Chome-13 Tsukiji, Chuo City, Tokyo 104-0045, Japan
description: A place well known by tourists but is also a favorite for locals. Can't go wrong with any of the sushi options here really and the fish is super fresh. Also, if you spot a tamagoyaki spot, give that a try too! Tamagoyaki is a japanese rolled omelet.

title: Ciel's Head Spa
address: 2-13-5 Minamiikebukuro, Ishikawa Building 2nd floor, Toshima-ku, Tokyo
description: Head spas are a common stop for those who have worked it into their budget (hint: it's expensive). Most places you go to will first assess your scalp before recommending a treatment. Most treatments include a good cleaning, massage, steamer, and deep conditioning. I haven't been to this particular location but have had similar service done elsewhere.
english: Doesn't look like it. Have your hotel concierge try helping you book!

title: Hayato Salon Roppongi
address: 3 Chome−7−1 Roppongi, Tokyo Plaza 206, Minato City, Tokyo, 106-0032
description: This was my go-to spot to get my hair done when I was living in Tokyo. The Japanese hair salon experience is differs from America with it's amazing customer service! They take their time, and most cuts include a mini head massage and complimentary drinks. You can add on a short head spa of hair treatment in addition to getting your hair cut.

title: Tsukiji Cooking
address: 6 Chome−22−3 Tsukiji, Wind Tsukiji Building 6F, Chuo City, Tokyo, 104-0045
description: I haven't done a cooking class in Tokyo just yet, but it's been on the bucket list for a while. This one had great reviews so if you go, let me know!

title: Watch a Sumo Tournament
address: Ryogoku Kokugikan Arena, 1 Chome-3-28 Yokoami, Sumida City, Tokyo, 130-0015
description: If you're traveling in January, May, or September you may be able to catch a Sumo Tournament! See here for booking tickets in English: sumo.pia.jp/en/

title: Shopping in Ginza
description: Filled with Department stores and stand-alone stores. Get your picture at Tokyo Plaza's Kaleidescope Staircase, then enjoy some shopping!

title: Samurai Museum
description: If you're a history nerd and are into it the Samurai Museum was cool! You can also add activities like Calligraphy lessons and sword lectures for extra costs.

title: Sensoji Temple
description: Senso-ji is the oldest temple in Tokyo and has the iconic red lanterns that you see in many pictures of Japan. Leading up to the temple also has a lot of street food shops, so it's best to go on an empty stomach and eat there!

title: Go Kart around Tokyo in costumes
description: This was another bucket list item that I didn't get too but I've had many friends do. Basically, you get to go-kart around popular areas of the city dressed in costumes like Mario Kart characters. Make sure to note that you'll probably need an international drivers permit, so make sure to check the website for more details!

title: Harajuku for food - Takeshita Street
description: Like its fashion, the cafes in Harajuku are well known to serve food that is also cute and colorful. You'll find lots of cafe-style places and some favorites things to eat include Creme Brulee Crepes and giant rainbow cotton candy.
english: Most places will have an english menu

title: Harajuku for shopping - Takeshita Street
description: Harajuku is Tokyo's center for colorful 'Kawaii' (cute) fasion. Great place to buy fun and quirky pieces or souvenirs.

title: Origami Kaikan (Origami Gallery)
description: Close to Akihabara, Origami Kaikan is a gallery where you can view multiple types of Origami, the art of paper folding. Viewing is free, but you can also take classes for a cost.

title: Shop for tech and 'Otaku' goods in Akihabara
description: Akihabara is known as Tokyo's center for tech and 'Otaku' goods. 'Otaku' goods are for anime, manga, video games and other collectibles.

title: Tokyo Skytree
address: 1 Chome-1-2 Oshiage, Sumida City, Tokyo 131-0045, Japan
description: Tokyo Skytree is a bit of a touristy stop, but on a clear day you can get a clear view of the city. It's similar to the Empire State building in New York or Willis Tower in Chicago.

title: Shop for Japanese kitchen items on Kappabashi Street
description: Kappabashi street is lined with shops selling restaurant and kitchen implements. If you're like me and love to cook, it's a great place for souvenirs! I love to get ceramics and glassware here!
english: Not sure but shop owners will probably know a little!

title: Karaoke at Rainbow Karaoke
address: 1 Chome−21−3 Jinnan, Shibuya Modi, Shibuya City, Tokyo, 150-0041
description: This was our go-to Karaoke place when I lived in Tokyo. Nice, clean, and not too expesive compared to other places. They also have an all you can drink option.

title: Karaoke at Karaokekan
description: Karaokekan is one of the largest chain karaoke places and have mutiple locations, which are noticeable by their bright blue sign with red letters. Fun fact - since the trains stop at 12:30am in Toyko, those who miss the last train during a night out, many people will go Karaoke bar until the trains start again at 4:30am since it's cheaper than a hotel.

title: Watch a Baseball Game
address: 1 Chome-3-61 Koraku, Bunkyo City, Tokyo 112-0004, Japan
description: Japanese people love their baseball and if you do too, you may want to check out a game!

title: Disneyland/Disney Sea Tokyo
description: It's a bit outside of Toyko, just east of Edogawa and accessible by train. If you're a fan of Disney's other amusement parks, you should check out the ones in Tokyo! They serve lots of fun and unique Disney themed food with a Japanese twist.

title: Odaiba Oedo Onsen
address: 2 Chome-6-3 Aomi, Koto City, Tokyo 135-0064, Japan
description: Onsens are public baths, a favorite among Japanese people and it's why there in most hotels and golf courses. If you want a particularly relaxing atmosphere you'll have to go to a Onsen/spa like Odaiba Oedo Onsen. Although, if your trip includes other parts of Japan outside of Tokyo, I would save your Onsen experience for other places since Tokyo Onsen's pale in comparison. Also, make sure to read up on Onsen etiquette ahead of time!

title: See the colorful Rainbow Bridge from Odaiba Marine Park
address: 1 Chome-4 Daiba, Minato City, Tokyo 135-0091, Japan
description: This is a common post dinner date spot at night as the bridge lights up in rainbow colors. If you want to see this, I'd recommend adding a few more things to do while you're out in Odaiba. Like stopping at the closeby malls, DiverCity or Aquacity, for dinner and shopping beforehand. Or maybe visit the Odaiba Onsen too.

title: Participate in a Tea Ceremony
address: 2 Chome-19-15 Kabukicho 9F, Shinjuku City, Tokyo 160-0021, Japan
description: Participating in a Tea Ceremony is a bit touristy but I highly recommend it to first-timers to Tokyo. With traditionally prepared tea, things like, how you whisk it, the temperature of the water, and so on, are very important and it's fun to experience once or twice.

title: Stay a night at Nine Hours capsule hotel
description: Capsule hotels came about when Japanese business men would go out drinking after work and miss the last train. Rather than taking a taxi (which is incredibly expensive in Japan), they would stay in a capsule hotel. The capsules at Nine Hours are about 43 inches wide, 43 inches tall, and 87 inches long equipped with a lights and USB charging ports. I recommend it for a fun one-night experience, but not for multiple night stays.

title: Shabu Shabu at Nabezo
description: If you've ever had Shabu Shabu (Japanese Hot Pot), Nabezo is a chain throughout Japan with pretty good quality meat for an fair price. If you want something a bit more afoordable, check out Onyasai Shabu Shabu!

title: Shabu Shabu at Onyasai
description: OnYasai is another Shabu Shabu (Japanese Hot Pot) chain throughout Japan. But it's a little cheaper than Nabezo, the other option I've recommended.

title: Fried Pork Cutlet at Katsukura
address: 5 Chome−24−2 Sendagaya, Takashima Times Square Building 14F, Shibuya City, Tokyo, 151-0051
description: This store specializes in Tonkastu, a Japanese style fried pork cutlet!

title: Fried Pork Cutlet at Tonkatsu Maisen Aoyama Honten
address: 4 Chome-8-5 Jingumae, Shibuya City, Tokyo 150-0001, Japan
description: Close to Harajuku, this store specializes in Tonkastu, a Japanese style fried pork cutlet!

title: Fried Beef Cutlet at Gyukatsu Motomura
description: This place specializes in Gyukatsu, fried beef cutlet. It comes to you fried, and you get a hot stone to finish grilling the meat with for a fresh taste.

title: Ramen at Ichiran
description: You can't go wrong eating at almost any ramen shop in Tokyo. But Ichiran is a favorite among tourists and locals, so the dinner line can get long at all locations.

title: Souffle Pancakes at Micasadeco
description: Micasadeco Cafe offers an assortment of food from pasta, sandwiches, and is known especially for their fluffy souffle pancakes.

title: Hike Mt. Fuji (summer only)
description: Mt Fuji is outside of Tokyo but this is another bucket list item that I didn't get around to doing myself. I have had a couple friends do it and really loved it. There is multiple tour groups you can choose from and you can either hike it all in one day or stay in a lodge half way up and continue hiking the next day. If you choose the lodge option, you'll be able to catch the morning sunrise at the top.

title: Grab drinks at the HUB
description: The HUB is a fun, 'British' Style Bar with locations all over Tokyo. It's a common stop for foreigners and gets crowded, so not the best place to unwind after a long day of exploring. It's more of a place to get hyped at before hitting the Karaoke bars or Clubs.

title: Shinjuku Golden Gai
address: 1 Chome-1-6 Kabukicho, Shinjuku City, Tokyo 160-0021, Japan
description: The Golden Gai is an area filled with bars and izakayas. Definetly a fun place to bar hop.

title: Roppongi for bars and clubs
description: Roppongi is the best place if you're looking for higher-tier bars or clubs.

title: Sushi at Sushi Zaimmai Okunoin
address: 4 Chome-5-12 Tsukiji, Chuo City, Tokyo 104-0045, Japan
description: If Tsukiji didn't satify you craving for sushi, this place is also really good.
